steps.title: Use a day planner or digital calendar.
steps.content: Use a day planner or digital calendar. [1] X Research source These will help you more precisely organize your time and keep up with your appointments. Enter appointments into your calendar as you make them. Then plan the rest of your days around those obligations. Try to plan your days the night before or first thing in the morning, before your day starts. Don’t start your day until you’ve planned it. If you have packed schedule, plan your day down to the hour. You can even allot time to tasks like breakfast and exercise, ensuring you get the most out of every day. Refer to your daily plan throughout the day to keep yourself on track. [2] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source If you go digital, give Google Calendar a try. You can sync it with your mobile phone or tablet so that you can check your schedule at any time, even when you’re on the go.

steps.title: Have a filing system for important documents.
steps.content: Have a filing system for important documents. Use a filing cabinet or organizer to keep track of documents, medical records, test results, and any other material that you may need for future appointments. This will prevent you from scrambling at the last minute, trying to find what you need, and being late to your appointments. [3] X Research source Alphabetize your files so that you can put your hands on whatever you need at any given time.

steps.title: Be aware of recurring appointments and deadlines.
steps.content: Be aware of recurring appointments and deadlines. If you see your dentist every 6 months, set a reminder for yourself to make that appointment well ahead of time. You can also set reminders for appointments that are time sensitive, so that you don’t miss a deadline or get caught off guard.

steps.title: Rank your appointments by importance and proximity.
steps.content: Rank your appointments by importance and proximity. When you’re preparing to make appointments, get your most important ones out of the way first. [4] X Research source If you have multiple appointments to make, group together any that have locations near to one another and set them back to back on the same day. This will save you an extra trip and keep your travel expenses down.

steps.title: Keep a phone list handy.
steps.content: Keep a phone list handy. These days, most people rely solely on their mobile phones to store important phone numbers. In general, that’s fine, but try to keep a written list of appointment phone numbers, just in case you have a phone malfunction and can’t access your contacts. Your digital calendar will likely store your contact numbers for you, but you might want to keep a written list anyway, on the off chance that you can’t access that, either.

steps.title: Call to make the appointment.
steps.content: Call to make the appointment. If you have a full day to plan, make your first appointment as early as possible and schedule the others consecutively. [5] X Research source Before you get off the phone with the individual who’s setting your appointment, ask for an approximate time length the appointment will last and if you should expect any wait time prior to your appointment. Based on that information, you can schedule another appointment on the same day, after that one. Ask the person setting your appointment to confirm the day and time you’ve just settled on. After they repeat back the correct information, enter the appointment into your calendar or planner.

steps.title: Calculate travel time for each appointment.
steps.content: Calculate travel time for each appointment. As you’re setting appointments and planning out your day, don’t forget to calculate how long it will take you to get from point A to point B. Keep travel times in mind when you’re making other appointments and scheduling other tasks for that same day. [6] X Research source Without factoring in travel time, you’ll end up running late pretty quickly. Don’t forget to include a time buffer between appointments, too. [7] X Research source Work out the travel time and then give yourself a small, additional cushion of time (5 to 15 minutes) for any unforeseen events or stops.

steps.title: Avoid over-scheduling yourself.
steps.content: Avoid over-scheduling yourself. Be realistic when you’re making appointments and scheduling your day. Don’t create an agenda for a day that’s impossible to follow accurately. Give yourself plenty of time between appointments and obligations so that your days aren’t stressful and so that you can stay on task. Don’t pressure yourself to fit everything into a single day. Prioritize and if there are a few things you just can’t get to, schedule them on another day. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Schedule time off from work or school in advance.
steps.content: Schedule time off from work or school in advance. Once you’ve set an appointment, notify your work or school about it well in advance to ensure you can be out on that day and time. Remind them the day before your appointment that it will be happening the next day. Confirm the time with them and give them the best time estimate you can for how long you’ll be out.

steps.title: Set reminders for your appointments.
steps.content: Set reminders for your appointments. Create an alarm on your cell phone to remind you anywhere from 30 minutes to 2 hours before your appointment is set to begin. Since most digital calendars have a reminder function, set a reminder the day before your appointment, as well, to cover your bases. [9] X Research source If you’ve synced your mobile phone or tablet with your calendar, you will receive reminders on all devices.

steps.title: Bring along any documents or materials you’ll need.
steps.content: Bring along any documents or materials you’ll need. Make sure you’re prepared for your appointment with the right materials, tools or paperwork necessary. In some cases, forgetting those items may delay or derail your appointment completely, and you’ll be forced to reschedule. Add a note to the reminder you set for the appointment that mentions any material you need to bring along with you.

steps.title: Plan to arrive early.
steps.content: Plan to arrive early. Leave for your appointment at least 15 minutes early. [10] X Research source If you plan to arrive at an appointment exactly at the appointment time, it’s highly possible that you’ll end up being late. Traffic and other unforeseen delays are common – you never know what you might encounter, so leave early to be sure you’re on time. [11] X Research source Get an early start on the day by setting your alarm a little earlier than you normally would, just in case. Make sure you give yourself enough time to complete your usual morning ritual without having to rush yourself or stress out. Establishments would much prefer you to be early rather than late, and most places appreciate when you arrive a little early anyway.

steps.title: Notify your next appointment if you’re held up.
steps.content: Notify your next appointment if you’re held up. If you have appointments scheduled back to back and you get delayed at the first one, step aside and make a call to your next appointment to notify them. Confirm with them that you can still keep your appointment if you’re a few minutes late. [12] X Research source Ask to reschedule for the same day if being late isn’t an option. If there are no appointments left for that day, apologize and reschedule your appointment for another day.

steps.title: Call and cancel as far in advance as possible.
steps.content: Call and cancel as far in advance as possible. If you can’t make it to an appointment, call them to cancel as soon as you possibly can. If possible, reschedule your appointment while you have them on the phone, since it might slip your mind later if you put it off. Occasionally, places will penalize you if you don’t notify them 24 hours in advance that you can’t make it to your appointment. [13] X Research source When you are making your original phone call to set up the appointment, inquire about their cancellation policies so that you won’t be caught off-guard.
